One time when I distilling by using fertilizer, i leave the units and go to do another things because I know its take more than 1 hour to be complete, after 30 minutes when I back to see how is going on, i saw the liquid from the flask come up to the distillation column ( spiral type ) and completely blocked the tubes..
the gas leaking from the flask joints..
I turned off the heater, and try taking out the joint from the flask, I was thought because the gas is leaking from flask, it may not cause any problem..so trying to pull out the joint from the glas who was hard and not easy ..Suddenly it get free and at the same moments , the hot boiling liquid with hot gas from that 1L flask are Sprinkle out like fountain , right all over the desk, my head, ,face and hands, You may thinking Im an idiot cos I did not wearing eyeglasses, no gloves, Right when it happens I feel burning from many points, badly, I rush to the water pump container, try washing my face and hands quickly..than running to the shower .. i was really thought that I going to lost my visions forever but when I come out and searching the damage in the mirror , I saw many points of injuries in my face, Forehead , even a few tiny points on the both eyes eyelid, so close to the entrance ( downside and upper side )
But thanks to God’s, no single drops are hitting eyes, its really a big miracle… the fact was the pressure inside the flask was so high…every single points are burned badly for the next a few hours..
I really recommending : keep the eyes on it until end of reaction, do not overload the flask, do not use fertilizer for this reaction, if you see the distillation tube are blocked, than Do not approach it whatsoever until it fully cooldown, always using eyewear …

I read that the density of 68% Nitric Acid solution is about 1.504g/mL. With that in mind, and your yield of 134mL, you should have 68% of 1.504g*134mL. This would mean you have 201.536g of 68% Nitric acid. Breaking it down further, the solution contains 137.04g of HNO3. The perfect yield, by stoichiometric conversion, is 251.8g. This means that 114.8g of Nitric acid were lost, likely in the weak solution among other things. I am not trying to demean you, just trying to figure out why so much was lost, because I personally don't know. Your yield was 54% of a perfect yield. Do you have an explanation of how that may have happened, or maybe I did something wrong in my calculations? Thanks

After doing this last night, I can add one thing. Run a vacuum. I used a cheap vacuum into a trap with some hydrogen peroxide in it expecting some NO2 gas. I had none. My initial reaction came out crystal clear, and the temp required was lower (of course).  I got a 37% HNO3 out of the reaction. I started to distill (fractional) again using vacuum getting a bunch of water around 72c. I didn't get to finish it out before I had to pack it up, but again, no NO2 and I'm up to 47%.

FYI Ammonium nitrate doesn't work hardly at all especially for use with silver processing. The nitric acid I got from distillation was extremely contaminated with what I assumed was ammonium sulfate and was weak at best. My sodium hydroxide trap actually grew a lot crystals just from reacting with the distillate vapor. I ended up using a lot of the byproducts to make sodium sulfate and I got a fairly significant yield. So it is a way to make sodium sulfate if you need it as drying agent or something as it's hygroscopic. When I used the nitric acid solution to dissolve silver and precipitate it with copper, I got a lot of white powder that precipitated out as well which made my silver difficult to process.

I actually tried this with ammonium nitrate and what happened was the ammonium nitrate rapidly started decomposing I turned off the heat and let it cool, then I added more water and tried again... it started distilling as it should but when I finished I waited too long to turn the heat off and the left over salt started decomposing. When I tested the new product it did not react like nitric acid and then I did a few more tests and it precipitated what looked like copper hydroxide when I poured it into copper sulfate solution. It then appeared to make the deep blue copper ammonium complex  when I continued to add it to the test tube. I concluded that I somehow had ammonium hydroxide instead of nitric acid. I was left with a dark red salt in the boiling flask. I’m not sure what happened but I learned that ammonium nitrate is not a good option.

I would like to add a probably unnecessary warning here. The narrator of this video appears to be very good at what he does. As a result, the process looks far easier than it actually is. Add to this the fact that he is employing professional grade laboratory equipment...it’s the first time I’ve seen anyone using a heating mantle on YouTube. This equipment is very expensive and may be hard to locate and procure. Even matching the sizes of the slip fit components can be confusing.

As far as manufacturing explosives...well, unless you are very well versed in lab procedures and are accustomed to working in a lab, don’t even consider it. I’m a FBI/US Army-trained Hazardous Devices Technician, worked as a weapons and explosives safety officer for a defense contractor, and formerly held state and federal licenses to manufacture high explosives. I’ve got a lot of training and experience. Having said that, I would be quite reluctant to engage in any such activity without a significant amount of very expensive preparation. Good luck!

I really don't like this method of distillation it's too much work for what you got adding the water seems like a big waste when you just have to take it out I don't see what the advantages of all. I don't get that much contamination in the first place so that couldn't be a reason. He cuts down on the foaming from potassium nitrate that was obvious but if your setups decent you can negate that as well. Most of the foaming occurs because people don't turn their heat back down when the reaction starts taking off. I did this in a 2 neck round bottom with a stopper on the extra port and had the stopper blast out violently and ejected a mix of sulfuric acid and potassium bisulfate everywhere. Thankfully I took every safety precaution, so I just had a lot of cleaning to do of my fume hood.

I'm still trying to figure out what happened. My setup looked nearly identical to the video.

- I had a way for the gas to escape through an acid trap (of water and sodium bicarbonate).
- It was only nearing the end of the reaction, when the round-bottom was about 90% solids, that the explosion occurred.
- After the explosion, my stir bar and a bunch of potassium bisulfate sludge was clogging the condenser.

Of course my initial thoughts are that somehow potassium bisulfate made it into my condenser, clogging it, and then the pressure buildup in my boiling flask caused the eruption. But I have no idea how that could have happened. Again - my setup looked just like the one in the video.

If anyone has any ideas please let me know.

Hi Nile! Why do you dont tell them how to make 99.9% Nitric acid? It's simple: Just take your obtained 68% Nitric acid and mix it with 98% Sulphuric acid (2:1) and do a simple destilation as shon in your movie. Then repeat this step and tadaaaa...: 99.9% Nitric acid. To explain it in a (very) simple way: the sulphuric acid "steal" and keeps the water from the nitric acid while the nitric acid distill's off.

But nice movie and perfectly explained! :-)

Kind regards and have a nice day

You can further concentrate the 68% nitric acid by adding dehydrating agents and then distilling it. Dehydrating agents include concentrated sulfuric acid; calcium nitrate and magnesium nitrate (U.S. Patent No. 864,217 to R. Wolfenstein and O. Boeters); magnesium nitrate (U.S. Patent No. 2,463,453 to A. P. Beardsley); and lithium nitrate (U.S. Patent No. 3,433,718 to A. W. Yodis). (See patent EP 0330351 A1 (1989) -- http://www.google.com/patents/EP0330351A1?cl=en )
